MainClaim.text: Heidegger's conception of the political in GA94 is characterised as a threat to ontology, and he systematically occludes the political in favour of the ontological.

Untitled 1.text: Heidegger's view of the political sphere in GA94 is negative and characterised as a threat to philosophy and ontology.

Untitled 2.text: Heidegger's presentation of the political as a threat is manifest at both a general and a specific level.

Untitled 3.text: The political is treated as a threat to ontology, and what is threatened is the distinctive role of philosophy.

Untitled 4.text: Heidegger's strategies for dealing with the threat of the political include disengagement, aggressive critique, and co-optation.

Untitled 5.text: Heidegger's response to the threat of the political involves relocating the political within his own metaphysical framework.

Untitled 6.text: Heidegger's presentation of the political as a threat is accompanied by a suppression of the political in favour of the ontological.

Untitled 7.text: The occlusion of the political in Heidegger's work has deeply problematic consequences.

Untitled 8.text: Heidegger's failure to recognize the economic and political as'realities with a logic and laws of their own' leads to a conceptual scheme that disrupts the use of binary concepts like Volk.

Untitled 9.text: The occlusion of the political in Heidegger's work is a distinctive move, unlike in the frameworks of Kant and Foucault.

Untitled 10.text: Heidegger's treatment of authenticity exemplifies a process whereby what are loosely ethical norms become gradually reinterpreted as ontological norms.

Untitled 11.text: The triangle with which I began is becoming eclipsed, as points (II) and (III) collapse into point (I).

Untitled 12.text: Heidegger's account of the sciences and his taxonomy of theory and practice are relevant to the discussion of the occlusion of the political.

Untitled 13.text: The occlusion of the political in Heidegger's work undermines his response to the charge that he allows ontology to occlude ethics and politics.

Untitled 14.text: Heidegger's privileging of ontological relations cannot be a transcendental condition of experience.
